section1List.hed: The Mad Genius of the Sonoran Hot Dog
section1List.dek: Why you should wrap your hot dogs in bacon. All summer long.
section1List.promoHed: This Hot Dog Makes No Sense. It's Still Ridiculously Delicious.
section1List.body:
It's a hot dog that seems like it was invented by a crazy person. Or maybe just a five-year-old. I mean, leave a kid alone in the kitchen with a hot dog, and it might end up covered in canned pinto beans, doused in salsa, squirted with mayo, and showered with potato chips crushed in little grubby hands. Right?

If you're handed a Sonoran hot dog, though, know that it isn't the mere product of chance and childhood neglect. There is logic behind the chaos of its toppings. Squint hard enough, and you might start to see a resemblance to the *torta*, a classic Mexican sandwich that also features beans, avocado, and mayonnaise. 

But the Sonoran hot dog is more than a mere Mexican sandwich. Instead of a base of carnitas, chorizo, or pollo asado, its foundation is a good ol' tube steak, wrapped in all-American bacon and grilled until crispy. And therein lies its genius. Just like [Spam *musubi*](http://www.seriouseats.com/recipes/2008/04/tutorial-how-to-make-hawaiian-spam-musubi-sushi.html), [Chicken Tikka Masala](http://www.teatime-mag.com/magazines/65-de/), Japanese [ramen burgers](http://www.japantimes.co.jp/life/2013/08/22/food/the-ramen-burger-that-ate-new-york/#.VWxxJGRVhBc), and Polish [*zapiekanki*](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zapiekanka), the Sonoran hot dog is the product of cross-cultural pollination, combining the best ideas from each culture into a Frankensteinian frankfurter that would be frightening if it weren't so delicious.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/556c8f5350e46c5c01e9aba1]|||
Bacon-wrapped hot dogs, ready for an avalanche of toppings.
|||

+++

The Sonoran dog starts out as American as you can imagine: With the patriotic combo of a regular ol' hot dog, candy-striped in bacon. As they cook on the grill, the fat of the bacon renders out, basting the dog with smoky flavor as it crisps. Youre gonna need that full-force crisp meatiness to stand up to the onslaught of Sonoran-style toppings. 

Think of it as a delicious clash of cultures. The warm grilled hot dog contrasts with the cool of avocado. The smokiness of hot, crispy bacon clashes with cool, refreshing pico de gallo. The blandness of pinto beans confronts the heat of pickled jalapeo. Crunchy potato chips go up against the squishiness of the bun. Potato chips? Yes, potato chips. Can you think of a reason why there shouldn't be potato chips?

And don't forget the bun. An ordinary hot dog bun simply wasn't designed to hold this much drama. Go for fancy hot dog rolls from bakeries, which tend to be heftier, or even a torpedo-shaped French roll. If you happen to score the authentic *bolillo* roll from a Mexican bakery, even better.

So where did this thing get created? According to Gustavo Arellano, author of *[Taco USA: How Mexican Food Conquered America](http://www.amazon.com/Taco-USA-Mexican-Conquered-America/dp/1439148627),* "the Sonoran hot dogat least in its American manifestation[travels] from Sonora in the 1950s and 1960s to Tucson in the 1980s to Tijuana in the 1990s to Los Angeles in the early 2000s, and it's been conquering states up I-5 and east on I-10 ever since."

But you don't need to memorize the Sonoran hot dog's biography to appreciate its strange power. One bite, and you'll understand.

[#recipe: /recipes/556c7ec35fa91f011a459430]|||
Sonoran Hot Dogs with Bacon, Pico de Gallo, and Avocado
|||

section1List.hed: The Summer of One-Pot Pasta
section1List.dek: When it comes to summertime pasta, easy does it.
section1List.promoHed: The 12 Best Summertime Pastas (No Cooking Required)
section1List.body:
Here's a secret: The simplest cooking doesn't actually involve cooking at all. Just curating the right ingredients. Which makes summer, so full of lovely and abundant produce, the ideal time to take it easy in the kitchen. You barely need to lift a finger to make a memorable mealjust gather up ripe produce and a few things from your pantry, and you're golden.

I learned this first-hand from my grandparents.

My grandfather preferred being outdoors to indoors and, for years, maintained a sizable vegetable garden to keep himself busy. There were bright red tomatoes heavy with juice, firm cucumbers with prickly spines, fistfuls of herbs, and zucchini that grew overnight into [veritable baseball bats](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/bigger-vegetables-better-than-small-article). Huge pumpkins dotted the perimeter. Melons, too.
 
And while he was outside harvesting, my grandmother was inside the kitchen bringing a pot of water to a boil for spaghetti.
  
One of my favorite meals as a child was what my grandma fondly refers to as "no-cook spaghetti." It's a slight misnomer, since the spaghetti itself is cooked and the heat it holds onto manages to wilt whatever sliced raw vegetable it touches, not to mention meld flavors, melt cheese and all the other delicious things that happen when heat, even if it is fleeting, is applied to good ingredients. 

My favorite version of no-cook (slightly-cook?) pasta was also my grandpas favorite.  A big bowl, preferably melamine, would get filled with chopped tomatoes (skin and seeds intact), enough olive oil to really make them shine, a bit of minced garlic, and enough salt to season the whole lot.  Hot pasta would get drained and mixed in, the tomatoes yielding ever so slightly and garlic tamed by the heat. Cubes of milky mozzarella got thrown on topthe most coveted bites were the ones where the cheese melted ever so slightly.

"No-cook spaghetti" is the essence of how I like to cook in the summer. A bit of chopping and a little carry-over heat from hot pasta are all you need to make satisfying meals that celebrate the best of summers produce (and sometimes you dont even need the heatthe noodles can be part of a cold, carby salad).  Plus who doesnt love a meal that requires just one pot and one bowl?  

Below are a dozen of my favorites. 

[#gallery: /galleries/556dc1625fa91f011a45a5a6]|||
Our Favorite No-Cook Summer Pastas
|||

section1List.hed: The Pie That's Easy Enough to Make Every Day (No Rolling Pin Required)
section1List.dek: Keep your rolling pin in the cupboardyou wont need it for this simple pie dough, which does double duty as both a crust and crumb topping.
section1List.promoHed: The Flakiest, Easiest, No-Rolling-Required Pie Crust
section1List.body:
Cold sweats at the sight of a rolling pin. 

Hives when you hear the word "crimping." 

A sinking of the stomach whenever you think of the 4th of July.

If these syndromes sound familiar, you may be one of the millions of people across the globe suffering from Fear of Pie Syndrome. Victims of FOPS live ironically tragic livesthey're terrified of making pie, but live to eat it. 

So here in the Epicurious Test Kitchen, we spent countless hours developing a cure: A pie crust that takes all the common pie anxieties out of the equation. No cutting the butter into flour. No rolling out the dough. In short: no stress. 

How'd we develop a flaky, no-roll, so-easy-you-can-make-it-on-a-Tuesday pie crust? The secrets are below. (Read it and weep, FOPS.)

####Use melted butter for a stir-together dough####
Cold butter is traditional for pie dough, but we found that melted butter makes for an equally flaky crust if you don't overwork the dough. And it's easy not to, since the dough comes together in just about 12 seconds. Start by whisking together flour, salt, and sugar in a large bowl. Forget using a food processor or pastry cutter to incorporate butter; just melt it and stir it in. A crumbly dough with pea-sized clumps will form, which is exactly what you want.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/556c7cea5fa91f011a459257]|||
Just your own two hands are all you need.
|||

+++

####Transform Dough into a Double-Duty Crumb Topping####
Once you've got pea-sized clumps, remove some of the mixture and place in another bowl. Stir in cinnamon and more sugar and you've magically got a crumb topping. Stash it in the freezer while you finish assembling the pie. You'll thank us later for eliminating the additional effort of shaping a top crust, and adding a delicious contrast of textures.

Next, add a splash of water and vinegar (for tang and tenderness) to the remaining dough mixture and keep stirring. Now you've got your crust! With a few kneads on a floured surface, it's good to go.

####Press your dough into the pan instead of rolling it####
Transfer the dough to a pie pan and push the dough into the bottom and up the sides using your fingertips. A flat-bottomed measuring cup will make this job even easier. If you want to get fancy, crimp the edge with a floured fork, or just leave it be. Place the pie pan in the freezer while you get the filling ready.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/556c7cea50e46c5c01e9a737]|||
Newborn baby pies in their muffin pan.
|||

+++

####Make Mini Pies!####
This recipe can be transformed from one glorious mama pie into 12 delightful baby pies that bake up even faster (and cool faster, too). Just double the pie crust and crumb topping recipe (but make a single recipe of the filling). Spray a 12-cup muffin tin with nonstick cooking spray, then divide pie dough evenly among the cups, pressing the dough into the bottom and up the sides. Divide the filling evenly among cups, sprinkle with the crumb topping (there'll be leftover toppingmore on that in a minute), and bake. These mini pies freeze beautifully (assuming they don't all get gobbled up right away). 

About that leftover crumb topping: Save it! Either freeze it for your next pie, crumble, or crisp, or spread it on a baking sheet and bake at 350F until golden brown (about 15 minutes). Let cool, then sprinkle over fresh fruit, ice cream, or yogurt.

[#recipe: /recipes/556c7ecf5fa91f011a45943c]|||
The Easiest Peach-Raspberry Pie with Press-In Crust
|||

section1List.hed: How to Slash a Hot Dog to Make It Extra Crispy
section1List.dek: When a crispy dog is more important than a juicy dog, break out a sharp knife and give that dog a cut.
section1List.promoHed: How to Slash a Hot Dog to Make it Extra Crispy
section1List.body:
Last month, I wrote with great seriousness and unusual depth about [the best way to cook a hot dog](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/the-best-method-for-cooking-hot-dogs-article). In that piece, I advised against putting dogs on the grill any longer than a few seconds (they'll only dry out), and advocated for dogs with natural casings (they have better snap). 

Today, I'm asking you to forget all that. Because today, we're talking about slashing your dogs. And while I'd never advise slashing into a natural casing hot dog, there's a dramatic whole world out there for skinless dogs. So why not explore it? 

Slashing is all about creating edges and ridges on a dog (anything to increase the dog's surface area) that will get crispy on the grill. These will not be the juiciest dogs in the worldall those slashes are just escape routes for moisturebut juiciness is not the point here. Crispiness is.


+++landscape-justified

[#image: /photos/55a0443d2165ea177986bc39]|||
Spiral-cut dogs on the grill.
|||

+++


Im sure we all know the trick of slicing a hot dog lengthwise, leaving a hinge attached, allowing you to open the sausage up. But thats child's play. The rage these days is to spiral-cut the hot dog, a trick a lot easier than it sounds. Here's how you do it: Spear a hot dog with a skewer or chop stick. Starting on one end, slice the hot dog on the bias, and then rotate the hot dog, leaving your knife in place as you turn the dog, until youve cut through the whole thing. Remove the hot dog, and then grill until nicely browned. 

Even easier is what I'll call the "wing cut"four or five slashes on the bias of each side of the hot dog, so that it looks sort of, kind of like a plane. A plane with five sets of wings. 

Temperature is meaningless here. What youre going for is an evenly browned exterior, one that's almost crunchy. You need a grill to make this happen. Note that while you gain crunch and browned flavor, you will lose the juiciness. But if you grill them right, these slashed dogs will be so damn crispy, you'll barely notice.

section1List.hed: 38 New Ways to Top Your Hot Dogs This Summer
section1List.dek: Because plain old ketchup and mustard aren't always enough.
section1List.promoHed: 38 Brilliant Ways to Upgrade Your Hot Dog Toppings
section1List.body:
Picture your ideal summer meal. Chances are, you're not thinking about a hot dog. And I totally understand. Why fantasize about tube steak topped with a squiggle of ketchup when you could be dreaming about burgers or barbecue? 

But hot dogs don't belong at your fancy hypothetical cookout. Hot dogs are for real lifefor those random Thursdays when you want to fire up the grill but don't want to stress out about smoking a rack of ribs or searing a steak just right.  

Just resist the urge to reach for the yellow mustard. Take the time (just a few minutes, I swear) to make a few special toppings. Just a little tweak here and a little twist there and you can put together an assortment of options for everyone to mix and match. Me, I'll be topping my dog with Chipotle BBQ Sauce, Sweet Pickle Relish, and Grilled Cornand then lining up for seconds. 

Here's how to make the best hot dog toppings happen:

##1. Spice up classic condiments##
Buy classic sauces. Stir in a couple extras. Done.

__Old Bay Mayo__: Stir 2 Tbsp. fresh lemon juice and 1 tsp. Old Bay seasoning into 1/2 cup mayonnaise; adjust to taste. 

__Harissa Ketchup__: Stir 1 tsp. harissa paste into 1/2 cup ketchup; adjust to taste. 

__Maple Mustard__: Stir 1/4 cup maple syrup into 1/4 cup Dijon mustard; adjust to taste. 

__Chipotle BBQ Sauce__: De-seed and mince 1 canned chipotle in adobo, stir into 1/2 cup barbecue sauce; adjust to taste.


##2. Grill your toppings##
Because if youre grilling hot dogs, why not add some vegetables to the grill to serve on top?

__Onions:__ Slice 2 red or yellow (or a mix of both) medium onions into thick rounds and grill until charred and soft. 

__Peppers:__ Quarter 2 peppers (a mix of bell and/or poblano) and remove seeds. Grill until charred and softened, then thinly slice. 

__Corn:__ Grill 2 husked ears of corn until charred, then slice kernels off. 

__Tomatoes:__ Thread 1 pint cherry tomatoes on skewers (or use a grill basket) and grill until charred and softened.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/556c8f3650e46c5c01e9aa40]||||||

+++

##3. Add crunch with pickles##
Make your own quick picklesor just jazz up the store-bought kind.

__Pickled Carrots:__ Shave 2 medium carrots into thin ribbons with a vegetable peeler and combine with 1/2 cup white wine vinegar, 1 tsp. kosher salt, and 1 tsp. toasted cumin seeds in a medium bowl. Let sit at least 10 minutes and strain before serving. 

__Pickled Cabbage:__ Place 1 cup thinly sliced purple cabbage in a large heatproof container or bowl. Toast 1 Tbsp. caraway seeds in a small pot over medium heat, then add 1 cup apple cider vinegar, 1 Tbsp. sugar, and 1 Tbsp. salt and bring to a boil. Pour over cabbage and let sit at least 10 minutes. Strain before serving. 

__Dill Pickle Relish:__ Combine 1 cup diced bread and butter pickles and 1/2 cup coarsely chopped fresh dill. 

__Scallion Kimchi:__ Combine 1/2 cup thinly sliced kimchi and 1/3 cup thinly sliced scallions. 

##4. Try a Combo##
Of course, you can mix and match these toppings any way you like. But here are the combos we couldn't stop eating in the Epi Test Kitchen.

__"The German":__ For a bratwurst-inspired dog, layer on __Maple Mustard__, __Pickled Cabbage__, and __Grilled Onions__. 

__"The Sweet + Smoky":__ For a dog that hits all the spicy sweet and smoky spots of your favorite backyard barbecue, layer on __Chipotle BBQ Sauce__, __Sweet Dill Pickle Relish__, and __Grilled Corn__. 

__"The Garden Dog":__ __Old Bay Mayo__ provides a creamy base for tart __Pickled Carrots__ and smoky __Grilled Peppers__. 

__"The Fire Starter":__ If spice and brine are your beats, mix together __Harissa Ketchup__, __Scallion Kimchi__, and __Grilled Peppers__. 

__"The Southern Belle":__ For a combo that's even better than your favorite summer succotash, top your dog with __Old Bay Mayo__, __Grilled Tomatoes__, and __Grilled Corn__.

section1List.hed: How to Slow-Cook Your Way Through Summer
section1List.dek: Don't pack away your slow cooker just yetit has just as much love to give in the balmy days ahead.
section1List.body:
Like thick wool sweaters and heavy rubber boots, slow cookers belong in the back of the closet when summer rolls around. Right? 

Wrong.

I'm here to tell you that kicking those appliances to the curb when the sun starts shining is a fool's move. Because on warm, sunny days, when the last thing you want to do is to coop up in the kitchen, the slow cooker is your secret ally, percolating a delicious dinner while you're soaking up the last few hours of sunlight on the patio.

*But wait*, you say. *I don't want to eat slow-simmered braises when the weather gets warm.* Actually, you only think you don't. With just a few tricks, these wintry braises (from some of our favorite new slow-cooker cookbooks) can transform into spectacular summer sandwiches. Here's how:

##Pile on a crunchy slaw##
What problem can't coleslaw solve? It's invincible, especially in the summer, when you crave all things cold and crunchy. And when piled high atop pulled pork on a split Kaiser roll, a [simple cole slaw](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/classic-coleslaw-51235880) brightens up the classic sandwich and makes it finger-licking perfection.

[#recipe: /recipes/5564a2d1100d9bda6d82287e]|||

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/556c915a5fa91f011a4598f0]||||||

+++

##Pull out the crusty bread##
Bread that's soft on the inside and nice and crusty on the outside elevates just about anything that's been slow-cooked. This is especially true for vegetables, which can all too often become mushy and lifeless. When peak summer produce like eggplant, bell peppers, zucchini, summer squash, and tomatoes are simmered until soft, stuffed into a split, crusty baguette and topped with a slice of Swiss cheese, just to gild the lily, you've got one killer vegetarian sandwich.

[#recipe: /recipes/5564a3d6644d45515b75a57e]|||
Ratatouille Sandwich
|||

##Shred it and Sauce it##
Chicken stew: Not summery. Pulled chicken pita with a cool yogurt sauce? Bring it. The brilliance of slow-cooker summer cooking is that the recipe for both of these things is the same. Just let those extra juicy chicken thighs cool down slightly, until you're able to pull it off the bone. Shred it, and add spoonfuls of the cooking liquid to moisten. Stuff the shredded chicken into halved and split pita, tuck the carrots in alongside, then dollop plenty of [tzatsiki](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/tsatsiki-242347)a cucumber yogurt sauceon top, to cool things down and add tang.

[#recipe: /recipes/5564a374644d45515b75a57a]|||
Spiced Chicken Stew with Carrots
|||

##Add lots of fresh herbs##
Ropa vieja, a traditional Cuban beef stew that's cooked until the meat falls apart, is delicious rib-stickingand severally lacking freshness. So how do you make it fit for summer eating? Pile it on a halved Italian hoagie roll spread with a bright-green, [herby chimichurri sauce](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/chimichurri-51169050) that's packed with fresh cilantro, parsley, and oregano.

[#recipe: /recipes/5564a1f8100d9bda6d822877]|||
Ropa Vieja
|||

section1List.hed: Grill Once, Eat All Week
section1List.dek: Fire up the grill on the weekend, and enjoy a slew of suppers all week long.
section1List.promoHed: Your Grilling Gameplan for a Week's Worth of Dinners
section1List.body:
We all have our backyard BBQ fantasy sequence. A slow-mo montage of a smoldering grill under a bright blue sky, and a table filled charred and smoky meat and cool, creamy salads. But let's be honest: How often does it actually, you know, *happen*? 

Most summer days, we just don't have the time to fire up that fantasy grill. We're lucky if we have time after work to untie our shoes before we fall on the couch and order takeout. But that doesn't mean the grill can't be your summertime savior. All you need is some strategy. 


+++landscape

[#image: /photos/556c6b195fa91f011a458f9c]||||||

+++

[#article: /articles/556dcbf186e2994e7b8f2dd0]||||||

####Grill everything on one day####
Make Sunday your grill day, and you'll have the fixings for dinner all the way through Thursday, all kissed by that BBQ smokiness. Big hunks of meat will stay juicy in the fridge for days, and summer vegetables will hold up for a day or two.

####Set up two heat zones on your grill####
Grab a beer (or three) and man your position: tongs in one hand, fork in the other. Spread the coals on one side of the grill, and you'll create two "cooking zones": One for direct searing and another for indirect smoky roasting. Nestle the hobo-packed potatoes in the embers and rotate the vegetables and meats over the grates, encasing them with flame and flare until the hold onto sweet smoketime spent investing in the flavor of the whole week's meals. 

####Make sauce and slaw that do double duty####
The chimichurri that you drizzle on your freshly grilled chicken is also the base for an herby salad dressing for a chef's salad later in the week. A pickled vegetable slaw that adds tang to pulled-pork banh mi sandwiches also gives punch to smoky pork ssam lettuce cups. You get the idea. 

##Sunday: Grill Day##

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/556c7eca50e46c5c01e9a875]|||

|||

+++

Today's the day to fire up the grill! Start out by lighting the grill, setting up the coals on one side to create direct and indirect heat zones. Nestle the [Hobo Pack Potatoes with Rosemary and Garlic](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/hobo-pack-potatoes-with-rosemary-and-garlic-56389625) alongside the coals, then set the grill grates into position and place the [Brown Sugar BBQ Pork Butt](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/brown-sugar-bbq-pork-butt-56389621) over indirect heat. While the pork cooks, place the [Garlic and Herb Spatchcock Grilled Chicken](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/garlic-and-herb-spatchcock-grilled-chicken-56389623), slabs of sliced zucchini, corn, and trimmed asparagus over direct heat until cooked through.

Set aside the grilled chicken breast, pork butt, and the remaining vegetables and chimichurri for dinners all week long, and then finish with grilled fruit and ice cream.

[#recipe: /recipes/556c7ecc5fa91f011a45943a]|||
Grilled Maple-Butter Apricots with Vanilla Ice Cream
|||

##Monday: ##

Time for Korean-style pork "tacos." Just reheat half of the BBQ pork in a 200F oven until hot, about 35 minutes. While pork reheats, cook rice, assemble quick pickles, and separate lettuce leaves for scooping up all that juicy pork.

[#recipe: /recipes/556c7ec450e46c5c01e9a86f]|||
Bo Ssm Grilled Pork and Pickled Slaw in Lettuce Cups 
|||

##Tuesday: ##
Cut the corn kernels off the cobs and chop the remaining grilled zucchini to stuff into summery, cheese-stuffed quesadillas.

[#recipe: /recipes/556c7ec95fa91f011a459436]|||
Grilled Corn, Zucchini, and Black Bean Quesadillas
|||

##Wednesday: ##

[#recipe: /recipes/556c7ec550e46c5c01e9a871]|||
Summer Chef's Salad with Grilled Pork, Chicken, and Chimichurri Ranch Dressing
|||

Time to use up that extra whole grilled chicken breast. Pull the meat from the bone and slice, and warm up 1 cup of the pork in a 200F oven until warm, about 10 minutes. While the pork is in the oven, chop up your salad ingredients, and use the leftover chimichurri as the base for a creamy ranch dressing.

##Thursday: ##
Shred the remaining pork and rewarm in a 200F oven until warm, about 10 minutes. Slice up the radishes and build your sandwiches using the pork and the remaining pickled slaw.

[#recipe: /recipes/556c7ec750e46c5c01e9a873]|||
Pork Banh Mi with Quick-Pickled Radishes and Carrots
|||

section1List.hed: How to Make a Creamy Berry Gratin in 5 Minutes
section1List.dek: Summer isn't complicated. Neither is this 5-minute dessert.
section1List.promoHed: How to Make a Creamy Berry Gratin in 5 Minutes
section1List.body:
Ever year, I strategically plan a trip home to New England in the middle of summer to go berry picking. And, yes, to see my family. But more to get some berries. 

[#package: /packages/5564b17d100d9bda6d822b4b]||||||

Located up a long, dirt road, the berry farm is perched on top of a hill and easy to get lost in for hours. Which is how I always end up spending too much time among the blueberry and raspberry bushes, leaving me with more pounds of each than I know what to do with.

A few summers ago, in a desperate attempt to find more ways to use my haul after baking my fair share of [muffins](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/cinnamon-blueberry-muffins-1222209) and [pies](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/the-easiest-peach-raspberry-pie-with-press-in-crust-56389627), I read a post by Deb Perelman  over at [Smitten Kitchen](http://smittenkitchen.com/blog/2010/07/raspberry-brown-sugar-gratin/). She was raving about a new way to use berries (a method she found on, ahem, Epicurious): the brown sugar gratin. 

Using just three ingredients, this 5-minute dessert doesn't require a recipe. You just need to follow three simple steps:

 1. Toss some berries into oven-safe ramekin or, if you're planning to serve a crowd, a larger gratin dish. 
 2. Spread sour cream on top of the berries until they're mostly covered, then sprinkle with plenty of brown sugar (light or darkdoesn't matter). 
 3. Place the ramekins or gratin dish under the broiler for a few minutes, until the sugar melts, bubbles, and begins to caramelize. Eat!

There's also no reason to limit this dessert to a mid-summer treat. Once berries go out of season, swap in thinly-sliced stone fruit like peaches, nectarines, or plums. Lucky enough to have access to fresh figs? It's hard to argue with just how great they'd be here. And come fall and winter, try bite-size chunks of apples or pearsanything to keep you satiated until berry-picking season rolls around again.

section2List.hed: How to Cook a Steak Dinner at the Campfire
section2List.dek: No pots or pans required. (Though you will need a few big rocks.)
section2List.promoHed: Why the Best Way to Cook Steak Is by Campfire
section2List.body:
[#package: /packages/558999be81ac1e502367a00b]|||
Cook It Like a Camper
|||

If there's ever an ideal time to reward yourself with a steakhouse dinner, it's after hiking all day with a 50-pound pack on your back. And yet, so much of camping cuisine revolves around ramen noodles and [dehydrated MREs](http://www.rei.com/c/freeze-dried-dinners?ir=category:freeze-dried-dinners&r=c&page=1)not much of a prize after a long trek in the woods.

But its easy to eat like a king (and less like an astronaut), especially when you have a campfire at your disposal. When I camp, I leave my gas-fueled stove and pots and pans at hometheres nothing worse than doing dishes in the darkand do all my cooking in, around, and above the fire. (Hey, if its enough for [Francis Mallmann](http://www.amazon.com/Mallmann-Fire-100-Recipes-Francis/dp/1579655378), its good enough for me.)

And theres more to campfire cooking than wienies and marshmallows on a stick. I like to make use of the fire from the moment its lit through the last glowing ember. Using these three techniques and some good ingredients, you can make a tent-side feast that can compete with one cooked in your home kitchen.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55881fa274cbe9ed7c20f037]|||
Start your steaks while the sun sets, and you'll have dessert by nightfall.
|||

+++

####On a Hot Rock####
Without a juicy, caramelized crust, there is no steakhouse steak. Sure, you could get that sizzling exterior by cooking your steak in a cast-iron pan, but who wants to lug one of those on the trail? Instead, steal a trick from fancy restaurants and sear the steak on a hot stone. 

Yes, right on a stone. A large, flat stone or two, heated in your campfire, will cook a steak as well as any cast-iron skillet, with a bonus of wood-smoke flavor. 

The ideal cooking rock is flat, about 2 inches thick, and slightly larger than your cut of meat. (Be careful with any rocks that are porous or have crackswhen heated, they may break apart). To get the rocks hot, build your fire on top of them and let the embers cover them as the fire burns down. Then simply brush them off and throw on the steaks. Alternatively, you can throw a rock or two (its always good to have a spare) on top of the burning logs or hot coals after the fire burns down a bit. 

[#recipe: /recipes/5588542c81ac1e50236790f4]|||
Steak on a Hot Rock with Wild-Herb Butter
|||

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5588199b81ac1e5023678917]|||
Kebabs cooking. All by themselves.
|||

+++

####Around the Fire####
Sure, potatoes are the classic partner for steak, but a plate of fire-singed vegetable kebabs is more colorful (not to mention juicier). And you don't need to roast those kebabs like marshmallows. Instead, take a cue from the Japanese, who like to cook their kebabs vertically in a pile of [*binchotan*](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-buy-charcoal-buying-guide-binchotan-article). It's a great way to utilize a roaring campfire, which usually has to burn down to smoldering coals before it can be used to cook. 

Once my fire is lit, Ill skewer some marinated vegetables and anchor them in the dirt about six inches away from the flames. Like an upright broiler, the fire will caramelize this Stonehenge of vegetable kebabs in just a few minutes. I usually use smaller ingredients like mushrooms and cherry tomatoes, but this method can be applied to almost anything you can stab onto a skewermeat and fish included.

[#recipe: /recipes/558854a874cbe9ed7c20f25b]||||||

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55881cf381ac1e50236789eb]|||
These ash-roasted sweet potatoes are pretty (and delicious) on the inside.
|||

+++

####In the Coals####
Ash-roasting vegetables may be a favorite technique among the New Nordic chef set, but campers have been doing it forever. By the time you've had your fill of steak and kebabs, your fire will probably have burned down to glowing embers. That's your cue to bury some fruit (apples, peaches, pears) or sweet vegetables (squash, sweet potatoes, etc.) into the ashes; theyll be ready in time for dessert. Their outsides might blacken and char, but inside theyll be soft and extra sweet, ready for you to cut them open and dig in (maybe with a couple charred marshmallows and a drizzle of maple syrup on top).

[#recipe: /recipes/5588537d74cbe9ed7c20f247]|||
Ash-Roasted Sweet Potatoes
|||

section2List.hed: How We Turned S'Mores into a Cookie
section2List.dek: Forget about stale graham crackers and unmelted chocolate.
section2List.promoHed: It's True: We Made S'mores Even Better.
section2List.body:
[#package: /packages/558999be81ac1e502367a00b]|||
Cook It Like a Camper
|||

It's almost a law of nature: You can't have a campfire without roasted marshmallows. And you can't have roasted marshmallows without someone wanting to make s'mores.

But it's time for some s'mores real talk. They might be gooey and chocolatey in your memories, but in reality? A s'more is almost never as good as you want it to be. Those boxed graham crackers are usually either too hard, making them hard to bite through, or stale or soggy from time spent in the cooler or someone's car trunk.

And then there's the chocolate. When does that thick piece of bar chocolate ever completely melt? Never. That's when. 

But we were convinced that the childhood s'mores could be transformed into a treat that even the most jaded adult camper would fall for. So we headed into the test kitchen to create S'mores 2.0. 

We were a little ruthless. We nixed the graham crackers altogether. Then we nixed the bar of chocolate. And in place of both, we created a graham-flavored, chocolate-dipped cookie. These things are moist, thanks to a healthy dose of honey and brown sugar; packed with cinnamon-graham flavor; and have a thin chocolate coating that melts perfectly when toasted marshmallows are sandwiched in between them. They freeze beautifully, so you can pack them in the cooler pull them out at the campfire. Or, if you *really* want to break with tradition, you can skip the campfire altogetherjust roast those marshmallows on a backyard grill and let the sandwiching commence.

Sacrilege? Perhaps. But sometimes you have to roast old traditions to create better ones.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55881ee174cbe9ed7c20ef52]|||
The textbook s'mores cookie moment.
|||

+++

##Create a chewy, graham-cracker-flavored cookie##
Traditional graham crackers are made with graham flour, a coarsely milled whole wheat flour. The ingredient isn't commonly available, so we used a combination of whole wheat and all-purpose flours to mimic the flavor. Using a mix of honey and sugar for the sweetener helped give a graham cracker-like flavor, as did a heaping spoonful of cinnamon. The honey also gave our cookie a nice moist texture, even if you've let them sit for a few days in the refrigerator.

##Add chunks of chocolate##
The first thing Food Editor Rhoda Boone said when we brainstormed ideas for this cookie? "I want it to have chunks of chocolate." Fair enough. Giving our s'mores cookies the chocolate chip treatment tastes as good as it sounds; each bite is packed with chocolate. To add enough chips but keep the sweetness level right, we went with bittersweet rather than the traditional semi.

##Dip Them##
After the problems of stale or too hard graham crackers, our second biggest frustration with traditional s'mores lies in chunk of the chocolate bar, which almost never melts through. In order to solve this, we applied a thin layer of melted chocolate (bittersweet again), to the flat side of each cookie. When the roasted marshmallows meet the cookies, the chocolate instantly melts, creating that luscious texture we always wish we'd get from s'mores of yore.

##Double Up On Marshmallows##
In order to make sure every bite of our sandwich has enough creamy, melted filling, we decided to pack on not one, but *two* roasted marshmallows inside each s'more sandwich. Pro tip: To maximize your 'mallow-toasting efficiency, look for branches with a "Y" shape, which will let you roast four marshmallows at a time, two on each branch. (Maybe even six, if you dare.) Be patient and hold the marshmallows near the edge of the flames to ensure slow and even toasted specimens, not flaming charred ones.

[#recipe: /recipes/5589b6da81ac1e502367a46e]|||
S'mores Sandwich Cookies
|||

section2List.hed: How to Pack Your Cooler for Camping the Right Way
section2List.dek: Want to keep your cool at the campfire? There's a trick to it.
section2List.promoHed: How to Pack Your Cooler for Camping the Right Way
section2List.body:
Camping is all about the skillsthe skills needed to trudge through the woods (where you might meet a bear!), the skills needed to build a fire. 

But while the ability to gather tinder, read a compass, and sip from a flask in the dark is important, even crucial, the most important skill comes into play before you even hit the trail: The 8-step process of packing food in a cooler.

##1. Gather everything you need##
Once you have [the menu](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-cook-a-steak-dinner-when-camping-menu-recipes-article) for your trip planned, map out exactly how much of each ingredient you'll need for every recipe and prep as much as you can for each meal in advance. Prep any vegetables you'll need, marinate your meats, pre-package [hobo packs for breakfast](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-a-hobo-pack-breakfast-for-camping-recipes-article), pack up small containers for condiments, and don't forget the salt. (Seriously. Do *not* forget the salt.) Because everything you pack in the cooler is probably going to get wet, make sure to package everything in leak-proof resealable containers or plastic bags.

##2. Score the right storage##
The thicker the walls, the better insulated the coolerand the longer it'll keep things cold. But it's not just the walls that matter: you want to make sure your cooler has a thick, well-insulated lid. If yours doesn't, you can help it out by packing a thick towel on top of everything under the lid. Also pay attention to how the cooler closes: Any lid that locks in place will help preserve the chilly temperature. We're fans of the tough, super-insulated, bear-proof (and very stylish) [coolers from Yeti](http://yeticoolers.com/tundra-35-cooler/). 

##3. Start with a cool cooler##
Coolers are built to retain temperature, whether it's hot *or* cold. So if you store your cooler in the hot attic of your house or the hot garage, make sure you bring it in the house and open it up to air out a day before packing it. Ideally, you'll want to get it cold. DJ Bell, the director of product marketing from Yeti Coolers, recommends dumping a "sacrificial" bag of ice in your empty cooler to chill it for at least a few hours before packing it. (Discard that ice before you start packingit's done its job.) 

##4. Chill what you'll be packing##
The colder the food and drink you put into a cooler, the longer it'll stay cold. Makes sense, right? So don't pack warm beers in your cooler: they'll just make everything else in there warm up and make the ice melt faster. Pre-chill everything before you pack, or, even better, pre-*freeze* it. Need to pack drinking water? Freeze it. Packing steak? Freeze it in its marinade in a leek-proof bag.

##5. Score a mix of ice##
For a one night trip, a couple reusable ice packs will do the trick, and will help keep things less messy. But for a longer haul, you need real ice. When you go to buy that ice, Bell wants you to "be an ice snob" and be choosy about which bags of ice you buy. He suggests that you "Don't get the stuff at the front of the freezerget the stuff that's like a solid block at the back of the freezer." The bigger the ice chunks, the more slowly they'll melt.

##6. Plan for a long haul##
First off, consider using multiple coolers, especially if you're feeding a larger crowd. If you can, use a separate cooler for drinks and a separate cooler for food. (The drinks cooler will probably get opened more often, keeping the more temperature-sensitive food cooler colder, longer.) If you're feeding a big group, you could even have a cooler for each day so you don't need to open up the cooler for your third day until the time comes. 

If you're packing enough food for a weekend trip, you'll want a mix of small ice cubes to chill things quickly, and big blocks to make the chill last longer. You can even throw in one or two reusable cooler packs (we like the ones with a freezing temp below that of water), which will help keep the ice cubes frozen longer. 

##7. Pack in layers##
When you start packing, start with a layer of ice on the bottom, then start adding in the items you need to stay coolest (like raw meat) on the bottom. Add another layer of ice, more food, and then more ice. Finish with foods that don't need much refrigeration, like vegetables. If you don't have a separate drinks cooler, pack your drinks on top, since they're the least perishable and will probably be the first thing you go digging for when you set up camp. 

##8. Keep your cooler's cool##
Remember: Air is the enemy in your cooler. If you have even a little bit of space at the top once you're done packing, throw in that towel. And once you get that cooler to camp, try and keep it out of direct sunlight, and resist the urge to open it more than necessary (without sacrificing your intake of beer, of course).

section2List.hed: Everything I Know About Camp Cooking I Learned From the Boy Scouts
section2List.dek: One food editor. Zero camping experience. 12 Boy Scouts.
section2List.promoHed: Camp Cooking With the Boy Scouts
section2List.body:
In 1998, I was a Boy Scout for 17 days.
 
Even at 11 years old, I knew the whole thing wasnt for me. First off, there was the never-ending series of *American Gladiator*-esque tasks built around the mundane act oftying knots? I could tie my shoes just fine, thanks.

Then there was the issue of sleep. I couldn't understand why anybody would sleep on the ground when they could sleep in a bed. 

And bugs. I hadand still havean absurd fear of bees, hornets, and wasps (no, Im not allergic). 

That was just the beginning. The list of reasons why it didnt work out between the Boy Scouts and me goes on and on. 

Two decades later I find myself rehashing those reasons as a I listen to my colleagues discuss plans for this weeks [Cook It Like a Camper package](http://www.epicurious.com/packages/camping-recipes-campfire-steak-smores-cookies-hobo-packs-package). My coworkers know a thing or two about campfire cookingthey talk about hobo packs and [dough boys](http://www.backpacker.com/cooking/recipes/dessert-recipes/jelly-doughboys/). Me? I talk about...nothing.

Because I don't know anything about camping. Because I'm a Boy Scouts dropout. Because in this conversation I am the exact opposite of what a Boy Scout is supposed to be: very much *not* prepared.

So I offer the only thing I can: To learn all the things I missed. How to build a campfire. How to cook on it. And how to sleep off the meal on the ground, surrounded by bugs. 

And I know just the people to teach me. 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55887d2274cbe9ed7c20f57f]||||||

+++

Two weeks later, I'm officially a temporary member of [Troop 19](https://www.facebook.com/BSA19SINY) out of Staten Island, NY. When I first meet my cohorts (a group of Scouts ages 11 to 16), they are piling out of an old, painted-over school bus. They look...*normal*. I'd expected marching in formation and compulsive flag saluting. But no. They're running around, laughing. They seem to really, really like the outdoors.

Things get a little more formal as soon as we arrive at our campsite, along the Delaware river in upstate New York. It's 4 PMa bit later than ideal due to what Scoutmaster Nick describes as an extremely competitive game of capture the flag on the morning river canoeing trip. Everyone kicks into high gear to get back on schedule so that all of the cooking, eating, and, most crucially, cleaning can be done before sunset. From this point on, everything will revolve around food. A hungry Boy Scout is a serious Boy Scout.

The troop splits into three patrols, each with leaders and a specific set of goals to accomplish. Troy, 15, begins building the large campfire that will serve as the cooking engine for the evening. EJ, 16, starts prepping the ingredients for the chicken fajitas that will eventually make its way into a Dutch oven on Troys fire. And Scoutmaster Nick watches over everything to make sure the process goes smoothly.

But, honestly, he doesnt have to intervene very often. Each of the kids knows what their tasks areand that no one eats if they don't accomplish them. 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/558aeca481ac1e502367ae4d]||||||

+++

It's only when I take a few of the kids aside for 10 minutes to pose for a portraitthe silly one up top featuring me (aka the grown-ass man dressed as a Boy Scout)that the kids break from their assigned routine. Miles, 11, takes the opportunity to show me something else entirely: Would you like to see a magic trick? he asks. 

He shows me a ring on his ring finger. But with a wave of his hand, the ring disappears. 

Another wave of his hand and the ring is back. 

I want to ask him how he does it, but everybody's back to the food. Troy's fire is progressing nicely, and I notice that he hasn't employed the ["teepee" method](http://www.primitiveways.com/Image3/Camp%20Fire%20photos/TeePeeCampfire.jpg) I expected. Instead of propping pieces of wood against each other in a circular formation ("they tend to fall in on each other and can smother a fire"), Troy has stacked the wood pieces in a square formation, Lincoln Logs-style. It's how I'll build my fires for the rest of my life.

Troy wraps chicken quesadillas in heavy-duty aluminum foil and places them just on the edge of the campfire's pile of smoldering coalsclose enough that it melts the cheese and crisps up the flour tortilla, but not enough to scorch the things, he explains. Meanwhile, EJ is prepping sliced chicken breast, onions, and bell peppers for fajitasthese kids seem to really love Mexican foodwith the care that a Michelin-starred chef might, except he's using cheap tongs instead of tweezers. With his messy curly hair and thin-rimmed glasses, he's the picture of a kid who hasn't quite grown into himself yet. 

I settle in next to him, start slicing onions, and ask him what he likes to cook. EJ thinks for a second, then serves up some Jacques Ppin-level wisdom: Sometimes the simplest meals are the most delicious ones, he says. 

That general ethos carries over into everything we make that night: crunchy, hard-shell tacos filled with ground beef, cheese, and shredded lettuce and EJ's fajitas cooked in a Dutch oven (yepjust surround the thing in coals and you can make just about any Dutch oven recipe work without the need for a propane stove). And then there are those quesadillas. They may not call to mind authentic Mexican street food, but they're damned deliciousthe perfect intersection of creamy, crispy, and chewy. 

I'm starting to realize that everything tastes better when it's tossed into the hot coals of the campfire. Even dessert. EJ decided to make the most complicated dish of the whole evening: Hollowed-out orange halves filled with thick brownie batter (made from a boxed mix), wrapped in aluminum foil, and tossed onto the campfire coals. The result is the naturally occurring version of those [milk chocolate-orange candy balls](http://www.amazon.com/Terrys-Chocolate-Orange-6-17-ounce-Packaging/dp/B001LN4IZS). 

Why these? Because they saw it on [Pinterest](https://www.pinterest.com/pin/39336196720188317/). 

I take the orange's top off and dive spoon-first into the thing. They're exactly what you'd expect: A messy, overly-sweet version of the two foods that birthed its Frankestein-esque existence. And a heck of a lot of fun to eat.  

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/558aeca374cbe9ed7c2105db]||||||

+++

As dinner wraps up, the troop mobilizes into what amounts to a human dishwasher. A few of the scouts have been assigned to KP, or Kitchen Patrolthat's how the Boy Scouts refer to (or disguise?) the crew that's responsible for clean up. Troy sets up three dish tubs on the floor next to one of the tables: one contains hot soapy water, another has just hot water for rinsing, and a third is filled with cold water and two [Steramine sanitizing tablets](http://www.amazon.com/Steramine-Quaternary-Sanitizing-Tablets-Sanitizer/dp/B00CBYBWWI). 

If none of this happens, the troop can't have their next meal. Plain and simple. (Oh yeahand dirty dishes can mean bears, as everyone keeps reminding me.)

As the Scouts clean up, I recap the events of the day with Scoutmaster Nick. Does he hope the kids learn how to cook? Or that they'll be able to defend themselves in the wild for the rest of their lives? Not exactly. "All of these things we teach the kids," explains Nick, "they're just tools to teach them the importance of leadership and accountability." They don't have to cook Mexican food for dinnerthey decided to because that's what they *wanted*. Camping put them face to face with the basic function of cooking: Feeding yourself and others.

The night ends with a game the troop calls Guns and Roses. Sadly, no part of this involves Troy and Miles dressed as Axl and Slash air guitar-playing hits from *Appetite for Destruction*. Instead, each of the scouts has to name three things: something that happened on the trip that they're thankful for (their "rose"), something they wish had gone differently (their "thorn"), and something to look forward to for next time (their "bud"). A popular thorn is that EJ and another Scout, Sam, tipped a fair number of canoes over on the river trip earlier in the day. 

After everyone goes around the circle, listing off their roses, thorns, and buds, it's my turn.

I wonder about my thorn. Should I have stayed in the Scouts all those years ago? Probably not. I don't regret the way I grew up. 
But I can't help but wonder if I could have discovered the importance of simple food at a younger age? Chances are it would have taken a lot less time for me to get there. 

The one thing I'm definitely thankful for? Learning the glory of a campfire quesadilla. 

My "bud"? Learning how Miles pulled off that magic trick. 

[#recipe: /recipes/5589938274cbe9ed7c20fd40]||||||

section2List.seoDescription: Our adult writer joins a Boy Scout troop to learn how to cook like a camper.

section2List.hed: How to Make a Camp Cocktail
section2List.dek: Because sometimes you get thirsty on the trails. For more than just water.
section2List.promoHed: The Ultimate Portable Cocktail for Summer
section2List.body:
When it comes to boozing in the backwoods, theres only one category of libation, in my opinion, thats fit for camping: hard liquor. Wine is too bulky for the punch it packs, and beer only makes sense if youre car-camping/glamping with ample ice on hand. 

[#package: /packages/558999be81ac1e502367a00b]|||
Cook It Like a Camper
|||

Plus, there are many ways a bottle of hoochbe it whiskey, rum or vodkacan help you out when you're camping. In fact, liquor is the liquid equivalent of a Swiss Army knife, when you think about it. Here are a just a few more things that booze can do:

1. Local anesthetic: A sip for the pain, a splash for the gash.
2. Mouthwash: Erases morning breathand you dont have to spit!
3. Fire-starter: Soggy wood cant compete with cask-strength hooch.  
4. Insect repellent: If they bite, theyll fly home drunk.
5. Sleeping aid: This one you already knew.

As such, I always keep a flask of high-proof spirit in my backpack. But recently Ive become a supporter of flask cocktails for camping as well. These portable drinksa favorite among itinerant bartendersare designed to be drunk at room temperature or, when camping, the clime of the great outdoors. 

What makes a good flask cocktail? Lets start by eliminating anything that contains fresh citrus juice or dairy (save your daiquiris and pia coladas for when you return to civilizationand freezers). Build your drink around a high-quality spirit, keeping in mind that brown spirits (whiskey, brandy, rum, aged tequila) fare better at room temperature than clear ones (gin, vodka). Next, choose a template: brown spirit-heavy drinkssuch [Old Fashioneds](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/old-fashioned-350766), [Sazeracs](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/sazerac-51193070), [Manhattans](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/manhattan-350780), and the endless variations they spawnare a great place to start, as they taste great at almost any temperature. 

##Try something smoky##
You're already cooking your dinner on the campfire. Why not infuse that smoky taste into your camp cocktails, too? A drink with a splash of peaty Scotch will do the trick.

[#recipe: /recipes/5588529b81ac1e50236790e3]|||
Goodnight, Irene Cocktail
|||

##Dont forget about water##
For drinks heavy with high-proof spirits, youll want to dilute the drink to taste in order to smooth it out (I usually add about 25 percent water, depending on the proof of the base spirit).

[#recipe: /recipes/558852e181ac1e50236790e5]|||
Kumbaya Cocktail
|||


##Load your flask##
When backpacking, I leave my metal flask at home and opt for a lightweight plastic one. Stanley makes [a great one](http://www.llbean.com/llb/shop/80226?productId=1333676&attrValue_0=Navy&mr:trackingCode=42D1E228-2EF3-E211-A497-90E2BA285E75&mr:referralID=NA&mr:device=c&mr:adType=plaonline&mkwid=YhvIVoh8_dc&pcrid=57704150480&qs=3091384_google&product=0NJT120000&cvosrc=cse.google.0NJT120000&cvo_crid=57704150480), as does [Nalgene](http://www.rei.com/product/836469/nalgene-flask-12-fl-oz), but I particularly love cheap disposable flasks [like this one](http://www.disposableflasks.com/). Going on a longer trek? Batch a bunch of drinks in a water bottle and know that the faster you consume it, the lighter your load will be the next day.

section2List.hed: How to Make a Hobo Pack Breakfast
section2List.dek: Because you don't *really* want granola bars and bananas when you wake up in a tent.
section2List.promoHed: How to Make a Hobo Pack Breakfast
section2List.body:
When you think about it, camping is a lot like staying at a hotel. You're sleeping in an unfamiliar place. You don't have all the comforts of home. And sometimes, all you get in the morning is a cold muffin and a carton of juice.

Is that the kind of breakfast that can fuel you through a day of hiking? Hardly. That's why our food editor Rhoda Boone created this trio of hot, hearty, make-ahead breakfasts. Wrap them in parchment and foil to create a "hobo pack," toss the packs in the cooler before you hit the road, and throw them on the fire in the morning. You'll have a hot breakfast in minutes, with plenty of time to spare before you check, or, um, *trek* out. 

####Stick to quick-cooking (or precooked) ingredients####

You don't want to wait hours for your breakfast to cook on your campfire, so you need ingredients that cook in just a few minutes. That means using a few pre-cooked ingredients, like sausage links and frozen hash brown shreds. (Another upside to pre-cooked ingredients: They're safer to store in coolers, and you don't have to worry about cooking them perfectly on the campfire.) 

[#recipe: /recipes/55832bc674cbe9ed7c20e492]|||
Breakfast Hobo Packs with Hash Brown Potatoes, Sausage, and Scallions
|||

####Cook, crack in the eggs, cook more####
Even with pre-cooked ingredients (like the canned beans in the Mexican-inspired recipe below), you'll want to cook them together a bit more in the packs before cracking in the eggs. Otherwise, your eggs will be seriously overcooked (and if you want overcooked eggs, stay in that aforementioned hotel!) 

[#recipe: /recipes/55832b5681ac1e5023677fc0]|||
Breakfast Taco Hobo Packs with Black Beans, Zucchini, and Corn
|||

####Finish with a fresh topping####
When you pull your hobo pack open, it'll release a puff of steam. It will smell delicious. Your appetite, sharpened by way too much hiking, will be triggered. You will want to dig right in. But resist the urge (you'll only burn your tongue, after all). Instead, take a moment to shower your eggs with something tasty, like the grated Parmesan and torn basil that you've packed as a garnish for the Italian-style breakfast here. It's just a small thing, but out there in the wilderness, it's the 5-star treatment.

[#recipe: /recipes/55832ad174cbe9ed7c20e488]|||
Breakfast Hobo Packs with Polenta, Prosciutto, and Cherry Tomatoes
|||

section5List.hed: How to Make Ice Cream Instantly
section5List.dek: You've had [ice cream sandwiches](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/7-new-ways-to-make-ice-cream-sandwiches-article). Now try sandwich ice cream.
section5List.seoTitle: How to Make Three-Ingredient Vegan Ice Cream Instantly
section5List.seoDescription: Using only three ingredients and a food processor for this vegan ice cream.
section5List.socialTitle: How to Make Instant Ice Cream Even Better
section5List.socialDescription: Hint: It involves peanut butter and jelly.
section5List.body:
If I told you that ice cream can be made in mere minutes in a food processor, and it will actually be kind of good for you, would you believe me? 

Yeah, I wouldn't believe me either. Luckily, nobody has to take my word for itlast year, food blogs erupted with [the idea of a two-ingredient ice cream](http://sharedappetite.com/recipes/2-ingredient-paleo-nutella-banana-ice-cream/), a semi-frozen concoction that's dangerously easy to make and has a texture just like soft serve. To make it, you take frozen bananas and blend them with a nut butter. That's ityou just grab a spoon and eat.

[#article: /articles/551d5174e7851a541a30c95b]||||||

It's an idea that's almost too perfectso easy and streamlined that it seemed like it couldn't possibly be improved upon. But with the help of the Epicurious food team, I believe I did just that.

I started by taking [Reginalds White Chocolate Macadamia](http://reginaldshomemade.com/products/white-chocolate-macadamia-peanut-butter), a natural peanut butter from [our peanut butter tasting](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/best-creamy-peanut-butters-in-america-article) and blending it with some frozen bananas. Not bad, but not ice cream. And not very sweet, either, thanks to the natural-style peanut butter.

For the next test, the test kitchen pulled one of the mass-market peanut butters [from our taste test](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/best-creamy-peanut-butters-in-america-article) that ranked very high in sweetness. This peanut butter's composition was also creamier and fluffier than Reginald's, which the food team thought would pull the "ice cream" together better. It all workeduntil the aftertaste, which was still bland and flat. Turns out, two-ingredient ice cream tastes a bit, well, two-dimensional.

Roasting the bananas seemed like a way to add depth, but that flavor came at a cost. The roasting ended up drying out the bananas, which made the texture of the ice cream more like a cool marshmallow than a frozen dessert.

A little magic from assistant food editor Katherine Sacks changed everything. While testing the ice creams one day, she was struck by inspiration. I saw grape jelly out of the corner of my eye and decided to add that, Katherine said. The result was a creamy, frosty take on (you guessed it) the classic PB&Jand a fruity and tart fix to an otherwise flat-tasting frozen dessert. 

This is a dessert thats best eaten as soon as its ready. If you want to make it for a dinner party, freeze the banana chunks while setting up for dinnercome dessert time, just pull out the food processor and make ice cream in front of your guests eyes in just a couple minutes.

Just like magic. Vegan, peanut-buttery magic.

[#recipe: /recipes/55ccb8876a622aab4ea63b35]||||||

fields.title: Peanut Butter Jelly and Banana Ice Cream
fields.credit: Photo by Chelsea Kyle, Prop Styling by Alex Brannian, Food Styling by Michelle Gatton

section5List.hed: 7 New Takes on Ice Cream Sandwiches
section5List.dek: Why mess with perfection? Because you can.
section5List.promoHed: The Ultimate Ice Cream Sandwich Riffs
section5List.body:
Hand me a good old fashioned ice cream sandwich and I won't complain. I grew up on the kind made of soft, rectangular chocolate wafers that always stick to your fingers, and it never did me wrong. I even kinda liked that freezer burn flavor they sometimes had. 

But lately I've been questioning the very foundation of these childhood treats. Does ice cream even want to be sandwiched? Why is vanilla the inevitable flavor of choice? And what's with those weird, soft, rectangular cookies?

Natasha Case, co-founder of [Coolhaus](https://eatcoolhaus.com/), an L.A.-based ice-cream sandwich company with food trucks in L.A., New York, and Dallas, understands my need to move beyond the old-school sandwich. "Start by mixing a pinch of salt into store-bought ice cream to bring out the flavor of both the cookie and the ice cream," Case says. "Or spike the ice cream with a little alcohol." (Cointreau or amaretto are especially delicious here.) Finish it off by rolling the sides in something delicious. "Crushed hard cookie crumbs are always great and sprinkles are fun, colorful, and look cute," Case says.

Most important? Don't limit yourself to those smooshy cookiesthe food editors in the Epicurious test kitchen certainly didn't. 

[#video: /videos/55d206f754b469aa41d13f77]|||
|||

Here are 7 seriously awesome combinations we came up with that break the mold (or the wrapper?):

##The Dog'wich##
*Hot dog bun + coconut ice cream + mangos + salted peanuts*

This [Thai-style ice cream combo](http://www.saveur.com/article/Recipes/Pok-Pok) will make you think of hot dog buns in a strange, but delicious way. The soft, mild bread combines perfectly with creamy coconut ice cream. Add diced mangoes and chopped roasted, salted peanuts and it's basically like you took a trip to Thailand, but not.

##The Biscuit'wich##
*Biscuit + peach ice cream + peach jam*

Upgrade classic [shortcake](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/whiskeyed-peach-shortcakes-56389789) by swiping a split biscuit with a layer of peach jam before filling it with a big ol' scoop of ice cream. You may need a spoon, a fork, and a knife to eat it. You won't care.

##The Brownie'wich##
*Brownies + mint chocolate chip ice cream*

We bet that [brownies](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/fudgy-double-chocolate-brownies-56389363) have always felt a little hostile towards cookies for having all the ice cream sandwich funnow it's payback time.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce22e86a622aab4ea641b7]||||||

+++

##The Donut'Wich##
*Cinnamon-sugar cake donut + coffee ice cream + chocolate covered espresso beans*

We wouldn't blame you if you ate this sweet twist on the classic morning combination for breakfast. Hey, if the [Sicilians eat ice cream for breakfast](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/sicilian-ice-cream-sandwiches-239168), why can't you?

##The Croissant'wich##
*Croissant + strawberry ice cream + strawberry jam*

A flaky, buttery croissant on its own is all well and good. But when you think about it, those airy pockets are meant to be filled with ice cream. Slather a layer of strawberry jam on the split pastry before piling in the ice cream just for good measure. 

##The PB'wich##
*Peanut butter cookies + black raspberry ice cream + salted peanuts*

A PB&J sandwich meets an ice cream sandwich and they live happily ever after. After smooshing the [cookies](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/peanut-butter-cookies-367212) with ice cream, roll the sides in chopped roasted, salted peanuts to add just a little crunch in every bite.

##The Waffle'wich##
*Waffles + butter pecan ice cream*

Whether you use frozen waffles from the store or save a few after [whipping up a batch](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/raised-waffles-40050) over the weekend, you will want to spread them with caramel-scented butter pecan. Tuck some sliced strawberries inside and roll the sides in chopped pecans, too. Because you can.

section5List.hed: The Secret to the Best 3-Ingredient No-Churn Ice Cream
section5List.dek: No ice cream machine? No problem.
section5List.body:
Are you the kind of cook who can whip up perfectly silky crme anglaise without heart palpitations? Do you have an insanely fancy kitchen, complete with ice cream maker? No? Bummer. No homemade ice cream for you, I guess. 

Actually, not so fast. A little thing called the internet has a solution: Fold together a combo of sweetened condensed milk and whipped cream, pour it into a loaf pan, and freeze until firm. No custard. No machines. Just cold, creamy joy.

I should know. I tried it myself. But when I ate that first batch of internet-approved no-churn ice cream, I felt something was missing. Sure, the texture was perfect pillowy. The flavor was pure dairy deliciousness. But the more scoops I ate, the more I started thinking about how I could make it even better. 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce21f36a622aab4ea6419b]|||
Folding whipped cream into the DIY caramel
|||

+++

Because I can't think about cans of sweetened condensed milk without thinking of turning it into caramel. And not just any caramel: When you [simmer a still-sealed can of condensed milk](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/homemade-dulce-de-leche-395011), it, well, *caramelizes* into that especially creamy, luscious caramel known as dulce de leche. (Try it. It's sort of magic.)

Now, you *could* let that dulce de leche cool and just pour it over your ice cream... 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55cb9b376a622aab4ea638e1]|||
Don't forget the flaky salt!
|||

+++

...or you could turn it into the ice cream itself.

Think about it: If one can of sweetened condensed milk can be made into no-churn ice cream, wouldn't the same be true of dulce de leche? Turns out the answer is yesit makes a phenomenally easy (and creamy) caramel ice cream. And what's better than caramel ice cream? Nothing. Except *salted* caramel ice cream. So I broke out the flaky sea salt and added some into the mix. (Note: Any kind of salt will make the ice cream taste better, but only flaky sea salt will add that satisfying crunch when you sprinkle it on top for serving.) 

Savor the ice cream all by itself, or top it with anything that goes with caramel: Toasted brioche cubes, sliced strawberries or peaches, or a drizzle of melted chocolate. And of course, one more pinch of crunchy salt.

[#recipe: /recipes/55ccb9254b068015388056c9]|||
No-Churn Salted Caramel Ice Cream
|||

section5List.hed: How to Recreate Your Favorite Ice Cream Truck Treats
section5List.dek: No need to flag down the neighborhood ice cream truck.
section5List.promoHed: How to Make DIY Ice Cream Truck Treats
section5List.body:
We all know what it [sounds like](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eBlyC9bJacs). 

You can hear coming down the block. 

Of course, I'm talking about the ice cream truck. An audible beacon of happiness during my childhood. A mobile dispensary of all things creamy, sugary, and iconically summer. As a kid, I'd chase after these treats with a fervor that was unmatched by my love of pizza, burgers, or pretty much anything else. 

But go back and try any of these treats today and, well, they don't quite match up to the memories of yesteryear. They can hang out for way too long at the bottom of a reach-in freezer, slowly growing a thick winter pelt of freezer burn. In an age of high-end ice cream parlors and premium gelato at the supermarket, these mass-market treats just don't quite cut it. 

So, I thought, why don't we make our own?

[#video: /videos/55d4eb0054b469aa41d147e0]||||||

####Ice Cream Tacos with Chocolate and Peanuts#### 
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce18404b06801538805d49]||||||

+++

[The Choco Taco](http://www.klondikebar.com/default.aspx?gclid=Cj0KEQjw0tCuBRDIjJ_Mlb6zzpQBEiQAyjCoBk-8rRRaeE1cIEBqguzn_l4HpSnhszrsBZYC_82_YGsaAjAO8P8HAQ&gclsrc=aw.ds#Choco) is genius on papera taco-shaped waffle cone filled with fudge-swirled ice cream, dipped in chocolate, and covered in peanuts. The biggest challenge was that shell, shaped like a hard taco but tasting like a waffle cone. There are [methods online](http://www.seriouseats.com/recipes/2009/02/how-to-make-a-choco-taco-from-scratch.html) that call for making homemade crpes, but we there had to be something simpler then that. The Test Kitchen's first attempt used hard-shell corn taco shells, which ended up tasting a bit too much like, well, corn. 

And then we cracked the code: Use store-bought waffle ice cream bowls instead. If you brush them with maple syrup and microwave for 30 seconds, the waffle bowls turn temporarily malleable. Act quickly, folding the now-limp shell into taco formation, then watch it magically harden into a vanilla ice cream-worthy vehicle. All that's left is to dip the thing in a combination of chocolate and coconut oil (aka ["magic shell"](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/how-to-make-your-own-chocolate-shell-with-just-two-ingredients-article)), along with some peanuts for that iconic crunch.

[#recipe: /recipes/55d4bdcf63b1ba1b5534b038]|||
Ice Cream Tacos With Chocolate and Peanuts
|||

####Strawberry Shortcake Ice Cream Bars####
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce18424b06801538805d55]||||||

+++

The original [strawberry shortcake bars](https://www.drumstick.com/nestle/bars-strawberry-shortcake.aspx) are great and all, but I could never tell you whatever, *exactly*, they're made ofvanilla, strawberry, and, er, crunchy stuff? A quick Google search reveals they're comprised of "artificially flavored creamy vanilla," a "strawberry center," and "an irresistible strawberry shortcake crumb coating." Luckily, I can tell you exactly what we put in [our DIY version](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/strawberry-shortcake-ice-cream-bars-56389962). It all starts by piling softened strawberry ice cream into a popsicle mold. While that's in the freezer, create a crumb topping by crushing up store-bought [freeze-dried strawberries](http://www.amazon.com/Natures-All-Foods-Freeze-Dried-Strawberries/dp/B005M4G4LI) and sugar cookies. 

As soon as the strawberry pops are hardened, remove them from the molds, and roll them in the berry crumbs. Repeat as often as required.

[#recipe: /recipes/55d4bd1b54b469aa41d144e8]|||
Strawberry Shortcake Ice Cream Bars
|||

####Chocolate-Dipped Ice Cream Cones with Peanuts#### 
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce18414b06801538805d4d]||||||

+++

[The Drumstick](https://www.drumstick.com/flavors/) was the simplest of all to recreate in our Test Kitchen. Start by drizzling the same chocolate-coconut oil mixture as the chocolate taco into a store-bought sugar cone, rotating it in your hands to completely coat the inside. After the inside is safely hardened, press a scoop of vanilla ice cream on top, dip the ice cream into the remaining "magic shell" mixture, and finish with a sprinkle of peanuts.

And there you have it. Truck treats without the chase. 

[#recipe: /recipes/55d4be5263b1ba1b5534b046]|||
Chocolate-Dipped Ice Cream Cones With Peanuts
|||

section5List.hed: How to Thaw Rock Hard Ice Cream and Make It Instantly Smooth
section5List.dek: Hint: It doesn't involve the microwave.
section5List.promoHed: How to Turn Rock-Hard Ice Cream Instantly Smooth
section5List.body:
Here's the scene: you decide to throw a last-minute dinner party, and you're totally prepped and organized. (You've probably made lists. A lot of lists.) Things go without a hitch, and soon it's time for dessert. So you pull out a pint of ice cream, planning to serve it alongside some crushed cookies and smoked nuts ([#Dadstyle](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/fathers-day-dessert-recipe-article)).

[#article: /articles/557762d274cbe9ed7c209ae7]||||||

But that's when all your careful planning hits a snag. Your scooper hits a substance that resembles just-poured concrete rather than ice cream. You strain, waving aside offers of assistance as you smile. "It's fine," you say. "Just a little cold is all." But the ice cream is not merely cold. It has, somehow, become one with the Earth's polar ice cap. And even if you took a power drill to it and busted it up into pieces, it wouldn't matterno one wants to eat frosty shards of dairy. Letting it sit out to defrost for a few minutes isn't a solution, either. It only results in a melty perimeter, leaving the icy core untouched.

What to do? Do what I did when I worked in the pastry kitchen at fine-dining restaurants (which just happens to be the same thing folks at mix-in places like [Cold Stone Creamery](https://www.coldstonecreamery.com/) and [Marble Slab](http://www.marbleslab.com/Default.aspx) do): Mash up that ice cream.

1. Take your ice cream out of the freezer. Let it soften for a few minutes, but no more than 5you want to thaw it just long enough to extricate it out of the container.

2. Place the ice cream into the bowl of a stand mixer* fit with the paddle attachment. Mix on medium until the ice cream is smooth and creamy. Be careful not to mix too longit *will* get soupy. 

3. Instantly forget about that icy mess from moments before and serve that silky smooth ice cream stat.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce23764b06801538805d96]||||||

+++

##One more thing...##
Hold on. Your ice cream is already in the mixing bowl. So why not, you know, mix something into it? Take a cue from Cold Stone and blend in anything you'd try as a topping for ice creamcrushed cookies, chopped fresh fruit or berries, toasted nuts, candy, chocolateeven crushed sugar cones.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce23756a622aab4ea641c5]||||||

+++

*Don't have a stand mixer? You can also break up the hard ice cream into pieces in a large bowl, using a knife if you need to, and then mash the ice cream until smooth with a potato masher. Once smooth, stir in the toppings with a heavy-duty wooden spoon. Just keep in mind that this method will take a bit longer, so the ice cream may get too soft, and you'll want to stick it back in the freezer for 10 minutes or so before serving.

section5List.promoHed: Our Favorite Ice Cream Sundae Combinations
section5List.body:
Whats better than ice cream? Ice cream with stuff on it. But sometimes, even the best-planned creations can be a little too much. Just because gummy bears, vanilla wafers, sprinkles, peanut brittle, strawberries, marshmallows, and chocolate chips are all amazing on their own, it doesnt mean they all work together. 

You can make a killer sundae without turning it into a towering mess. Here are 10 simple-but-great sundae combinations that wont fall flat.

####Chocolate Ice Cream + Beer Syrup + Smoked Almonds####
Make a syrup from a chocolatey stout and crush up some smoked almonds to put on top=[sundaes for grown-ups](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/fathers-day-dessert-recipe-article).


####[Walnut Ice Cream](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/maple-walnut-ice-cream-104909) + Figs + Honey####
Roast the figs in brown sugar. Top the walnut ice cream with the figs as they come out of the oven. Your heart may melt as fast as the ice cream.


####Butter Pecan Ice Cream + [Candied Bacon](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/maple-pecan-sundaes-with-candied-bacon-361274) + Maple Syrup####
Take butter pecan ice cream and top it with some crumbled candied bacon and maple syrup for a decadent dessert thats got all of the flavors of breakfast.



####Salted Caramel Ice Cream + Pretzels + [DIY Magic Shell](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/peanut-butter-ice-cream-with-a-hard-chocolate-shell-51183420)####
Looking for a little extra crunch on your sundae? Use some DIY chocolate shell that freezes right on.
 


+++landscape


[#image: /photos/54af3391c4a891cc44ccb018]|||
Photo by Levi Brown
|||








text in callout


+++





####Vanilla Ice Cream + Fresh Peaches + Raspberry Preserves####
In more fancy circles, this is [called peach melba](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/peach-melba-with-burnt-caramel-sauce-51108610). You could make a complex caramelized sauce, but if you really want to keep it simple, use raspberry preserves and peak-of-season summer peaches.


####Coffee Ice Cream + [Coffee Caramel Sauce](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/coffee-caramel-sauce-5794) + Chocolate-Covered Espresso Beans####
Give that ice cream sundae a buzz with some eye-opening espresso flavor. Find chocolate-covered espresso beans in gourmet stores and candy shops.
 

####[Mint Chocolate Chip Ice Cream](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/mint-chip-ice-cream-56389914) + Brownies + Dark Chocolate####
Like Thin Mint cookies? This is how you get your frozen fix. Chop up [brownies](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/cocoa-brownies-51134540) for some added chewiness.

####Strawberry Ice Cream + White Chocolate + Strawberry Jam####
This simple three-punch sundae tastes just like a strawberry cheesecake without the baking, cooling, and slicing. So it's everything good without the wait.

####Black Cherry Ice Cream + Whipped Cream + [Cherry Pie](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/cherry-bourbon-pie-51108280)####
Youd put ice cream on top of a slice of piewhy not try a little role reversal? Crush up a pie slice, [make your whipped cream ahead of time](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-whipped-cream-ahead-of-time-article), and revel in the boozy take on a classic. 

####Pistachio Ice Cream + Chocolate Sauce + [Croissant](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/croissants-394749)####
This works just like the fruit pie trick. Tear the croissant into chunks and drizzle on some chocolate because, well, chocolate never hurt.
